c7114bd6-c4a1-395f-9a13-60808ba10280: This function configures the frame depth for the Ping-Pong buffers utilized by the DCI CSC, determining the number of frames loaded into the chosen buffer before triggering an interrupt. The initial frame depth is set by a parameter when starting the tmaliTask, with a maximum allowable value of 64 frames. If a value exceeding this maximum is requested, the timeout defaults to V frames. The frame depth adjustment may be slightly delayed if the DCI bus is active, and typically occurs when the DCI reports a frame level reached or a timeout, reducing the risk of altering the setting during a frame event detection. Modifying the frame depth while the DCI CSC is processing data may lead to unpredictable outcomes. If a new 'tmaliDciFrameDepthSet' command is issued before the previous one is applied, the new command will replace the old one, and the DCI will update to the new value as soon as possible.
bc6aa2ae-e95d-3d2c-96ed-bfec7c79a82b: The DPU-CCM CSC offers a centralized error reporting function, ccmErrEnq(), which other FSW tasks utilize to log errors. Upon activation, ccmTask() verifies if it's the appropriate time to compile an error/event packet for ground transmission. If it is, ccmTask() invokes ccmHkMkError() to generate the packet and send it to DPU-SCUI for ground transmission.
b8456530-0731-3508-9761-26e72feb24bd: This function allows for the configuration of DCI windowing parameters utilized in DCI data acquisition. It first verifies the window specification before instructing the DCI driver to modify the DCI hardware windowing parameters. If the specification is invalid, the function returns an error and does not activate the hardware windowing function. The function both configures the specified hardware window and activates the hardware windowing feature.
fb242af6-b3b1-33f8-8d78-87a3c7eb02f2: The DPU processes commands through two interfaces: the MIL-STD-1553 from the Spacecraft and the SSI from the ICU. Commands can be issued to the DPU by either the SCU or the ICU. The origin of a command to the DPU can be one of the following: ICU, where the command is created and transmitted by the ICU via SSI; SCU, where the command is created and transmitted by the SCU via 1553; G-ICU, where the command is created on the ground and sent to the DPU through the ICU/SSI; or G-SCU, where the command is created on the ground and sent to the DPU through the SCU/1553.
683bd169-7936-38f5-8ec6-450bb46b4193: During normal operations, frames are received roughly every 11 milliseconds. The DCI hardware triggers an interrupt if event data is present in one of the Ping-Pong buffers and a set period has elapsed without receiving additional events. This data timeout interrupt is not considered an error; it usually signifies the end of the current exposure. It enables the TMALI CSC to collect the remaining events from the DCI Ping-Pong buffer. The function tmaliDciTimeoutSet() offers an API for the DCI Driver to modify the timeout setting.
ae44d8bf-c14a-3d6c-8188-eeb470411d97: When the tmaliTransferToQueueISR() interrupt service routine is triggered, it signals a semaphore to wake up tmaliTask(), which will then transfer data to the queue via the VME bus. The tmaliTask() utilizes the read() function from the DCI Driver, which performs data transfer using a high-speed assembly language routine. Since the TMALI ring buffer is structured as an array, tmaliTask() must first check the TMALI_EVENT_QUEUE to decide if the data in the DCI buffer can be accessed with a single read() call or if two calls are necessary to manage the wrap-around scenario at the end of the ring buffer. Additionally, tmaliTask() must conduct an error check to ensure there is enough space to accommodate the data available in the Ping-Pong buffer. If there is not enough space for all the frames, the entire contents of the readable Ping-Pong buffer are discarded, and the error S_TMALI_QUEUE_FULL is reported using the ‘ccmErrEnq’ mechanism. The discarded data consists of a whole number of CCD frames, as the DCI hardware design ensures that Ping-Pong transitions occur at CCD frame boundaries. This approach of discarding newer data aligns with the scientific perspective that events collected immediately after a burst are more valuable than those collected later.
10357029-28da-33b2-b8f0-4713ee2e253e: The TMALI CSC gathers housekeeping data, which can be accessed through the function call tmaliHkGet(). The housekeeping information for TMALI CSC is provided in the TMALI_HK data structure.
e0293058-637f-3d06-9e93-58ad7eb7ab03: This function allows retrieval of the current data timeout value utilized by the DCI, returning the timeout duration in milliseconds. Details about the timeout can be found in document 036911400, section 4.3.2.4.1.3.
1efab1f4-2d51-36d5-ae38-547a16f3b35e: The MIL-STD-1553 Command ISR calls this routine at a frequency of 1 Hz (triggered by the arrival of the Clock Message) to activate the CCM Control Task, which waits on a semaphore after finishing its processing.
eb28cb30-0f34-3a3f-b57c-df4c8963973c: There are two methods for uploading data to the DPU: using the Memory Poke command (D_MEM_DAT_POKE) or the Memory Upload command (D_MEM_DAT_UPLD). The Memory Poke command is intended for inserting a small amount of data, up to Z bytes, into a DPU memory location. The Z byte limit is based on the command length restriction set by Company X.
f7de0734-27a2-34d8-bebc-d484804f8a15: To prevent loss of error counts due to rollover, ccmErrEnq() ensures that the error count for a specific error does not exceed 250 within a single high-rate housekeeping reporting period. If the error count surpasses 250 during this period, ccmErrEnq() will enqueue an S_ccm_ERR_REPEAT error with the current error count and reset its error tracking system.
ec46a357-6a43-3143-a8dc-e65da96c02a9: During the boot process, an error queue is not present as it has not been established yet. Errors occurring at this initial stage are directly assigned to the global task variable errno. For further details on errno, refer to section 2.3.7 of the VxWorks® Programmer’s Guide. Once the error queues are set up, any value assigned to errno is added to the Error Queue using the ccmErrEnq() function.
12fcc558-f3da-34c0-bc3a-2f83f04a9b35: In the ring buffer data structure, the pointers are defined as follows: pIn refers to the most recently filled data location, while pOut indicates the most recently emptied location.
1652e08e-b4e9-3cbc-8baf-e44503dc80dc: The Telescope Module Access Library and Interface (TMALI) CSC is responsible for handling the detector event queue and offers an API to access detector events from this queue for data processing algorithms.
4fe51fd2-4193-311d-bb29-8c2563a1947e: The routine is invoked by the MIL-STD-1553 Command ISR and the SSI Interface ISR whenever a command is received from the SCU or ICU, in order to queue the command and activate the CCM Command Dispatch Task for execution.
3c3f0e53-76e3-3513-950b-210756737aaa: The CSC uses a FIFO ring buffer to temporarily hold data from the DCI before processing. This ring buffer employs two pointers, pIn and pOut, to manage the data within it. The pointers are designed to make reading from the buffer straightforward, requiring only a single comparison to check if the buffer is empty. The buffer exclusively stores Events, with the pointers referencing these four-byte units. Since the DCI provides data in bytes, size conversions are necessary before data reading.
937a7360-cc59-3861-b114-8033971258fe: Global Data	the data elements that are accessed by this CSC on a global scale
67a9c981-0b81-3aa8-93c2-892b99bc6fb3: The CCM Control, upon execution, invokes ccmPerProcess() to manage periodic tasks such as updating analog to digital conversions, monitoring DPU tasks, generating ICU heartbeat messages, and activating the watchdog strobe. The ccmHealthChk() function, which is called by ccmPerProcess(), checks the execution of other tasks by tracking the time since each task last reported. Tasks report their execution status to the CCM Control Task by using the ccmTaskReport() function and providing their task index. Each task has a designated execution frequency, and if a task does not perform as expected, an error is logged in DPU housekeeping. If the Command Dispatch Task fails to report for a prolonged period, the DPU will reboot, as it cannot be commanded without this task running; otherwise, the watchdog will be strobed.
e374957b-ac53-36e6-a10e-a2a107476e2d: The D_MEM_BLK_DNLD command is used to download data from a file in the EEPROM filesystem. Similar to the upload command, only the block number is needed, and the entire file named after the block number will be downloaded. For downloading data from locations other than the EEPROM filesystem, the D_MEM_DAT_DNLD command is used. As previously mentioned, downloads are processed in a deferred manner to prevent excessive CPU usage. A single "virtual" download will be represented on the ground as a series of download packets, which must be extracted and combined to reconstruct the original data sequence.
f48fb390-633e-3d9b-9676-2ac43abbf741: Command Handling involves dequeuing commands from the Command Queue and executing them via the Command Dispatch Task, ccmCmdTask(). This task waits for a semaphore signal from ccmCmdEnq(). When the semaphore is triggered, ccmCmdTask() activates and calls ccmCmdProcess() to handle pending commands. The ccmCmdProcess() function retrieves commands from the Command Queue and uses ccmCmdDispatch() to check the command's expected length and execute it. If command echo is enabled, ccmCmdDispatch() will call ccmHkMkCmdEcho() to echo the command back to the ground without modification. Counts of both rejected and executed commands are tracked. Commands sent to ccmCmdEnq() that are either a 1 Hz Clock Time message or an Attitude message from the spacecraft are executed directly in the interrupt context and not added to the Command Queue. Attitude messages are sent to dpaCommandSend(), while the 1 Hz Clock Time message parameters are used by tisTimeSync() to synchronize the current time. Any other non-DPU or non-spacecraft observatory messages are discarded without error notification. To ensure that ccmCmdTask() periodically checks in with the CCM Control Task in the absence of ground commands, the semaphore has a 20-second timeout. If the semaphore times out, the task checks that no commands are in the Command Queue and then reports to the CCM Control Task by calling ccmTaskReport().
06730727-b965-350c-b24c-686e202a20c8: Data can be uploaded to various locations, such as DRAM, EEPROM, hardware registers, and the EEPROM filesystem. The D_MEM_DAT_UPLD command determines the target location. If the destination is the EEPROM filesystem, a "block number" is provided instead of a memory address, which the DPU FSW uses to create a filename in the format eefs1:DPU_blk.##, where ## represents the block number. Once all the data is uploaded to the DPU FSW, it is written to the specified file in the EEPROM filesystem. If a file with that name already exists, it will be overwritten. The EEPROM filesystem can be reset using the D_MEM_DISK_INIT command.
b4b9c2df-6803-3c2f-86c8-e0eba7a2f875: The DPA CSC uses tmaliWait() to check the number of pending EVENTs. If tmaliWait() indicates more than zero EVENTs, the DPA proceeds to call tmaliNextEvent() for each EVENT to be retrieved.
1c787708-25b7-38f8-91f5-850489556f6f: The DCI control/status register's bit arrangement can be configured using tmaliBitArrangementSet().
3be47e1c-6b7f-3ffb-8325-9630e9edd832: For uploading large memory amounts to the DPU, such as during a software patch or full software upload, the standard memory upload process is used. This involves sending multiple D_MEM_DAT_UPLD commands to create a single "virtual" upload. CCSDS-like sequence flags are used to enable the DPU FSW to handle up to 65535 bytes in one "virtual" upload. The data from each D_MEM_DAT_UPLD command is temporarily stored in a DRAM buffer until all sequence numbers for the upload are successfully received. Once the DPU FSW gets the final command in the series, it checks that all sequence numbers are received, verifies the end-to-end upload checksum, and then writes the entire temporary buffer to the target location specified in the initial upload command.
26dc1e1f-f2c8-3cf1-9dd5-a886e42f56d0: The CCM Control Task is responsible for initializing the DPU FSW and ensuring a successful boot by waiting on temporary semaphores with a 5-second timeout after starting the SCU Interface Task and the CCM Command Task. If both tasks signal successful initialization by releasing the semaphore, the CCM Control Task updates the BC_INDEX parameter in EEPROM to indicate a successful boot. If either task fails to initialize successfully, the CCM Control Task disables the watchdog strobe to trigger a DPU reboot. The successful initialization of these two tasks is crucial as they are necessary for establishing ground contact and enabling commandability of the DPU FSW. Once initialization is complete, the task waits on a binary semaphore, which is released by the SCUI Command ISR when the 1 Hz Clock Message arrives. If the Clock Message does not arrive, the semaphore times out after 1.5 seconds. The CCM Control Task continues to operate to generate and send DPU housekeeping data at set intervals, perform periodic processing tasks, and handle memory dump commands. The final call to ccmErrEnq() ensures that if an error occurs in an interrupt service routine, a global variable is set with the errno value, which is then added to the Error/Event Queue as part of the task's routine processing.
343828f3-f19a-3288-af11-a4f836e9c455: The hardware windowing feature of the DCI can be enabled and managed using tmaliDciWindowSet(). This function enables the hardware windowing feature and sends the defined window parameters to the DCI driver.
8f2f6899-8025-3fa9-b3d5-5ddf3dbeedcc: The DPU generates eight varieties of housekeeping packets for control and monitoring.
24ee9060-5104-362e-8674-f0f48477c68b: This function is invoked by any CSC to log an error or event for inclusion in DPU housekeeping. If called from an interrupt context, it sets a static global variable, ccmISRError, to allow the error to be queued later, as the error/event queue is protected by a semaphore, which cannot be acquired in an ISR. The semaphore for the error queue has priority inversion enabled to minimize conflicts among multiple callers in case of priority inversion. The function also substitutes frequently occurring errors with a special repeat error code, which follows a standard error code to indicate that the standard error code has been reported multiple times during the last high-rate reporting period.
fb1fc2fe-ac6f-360a-b867-6c1ba4bb1f17: The DPA CSC retrieves events from the TMALI_EVENT_QUEUE using an API with two functions: tmaliWait() and tmaliNextEvent(). For efficiency, the following points are important: the DPA CSC will inline the tmaliNextEvent() function to avoid a function call for each event; it will store each received event in a register and complete processing while the event is in the register before getting the next event; and the tmaliNextEvent() function does not perform error checking to enhance efficiency, so the DPA CSC must track the number of events retrieved compared to the number returned by tmaliWait().
e18f3e19-ae7b-3f8e-81b4-b8a4a6424184: The Command and Control CSC is initialized by creating the CCM Control Task, ccmCtrlTask(), from the operating system's startup task, usrRoot(). Once this task is created, it invokes the ccmInit() function, which sets up the error/event queue, creates necessary semaphores, and installs various ISRs. It then initiates the remaining tasks that make up the DPU FSW. Upon starting, the CCM Control Task retrieves DPU configuration startup defaults from the SYSTEM_CONFIG_AREA in EEPROM. If the checksum for SYSTEM_CONFIG_AREA is invalid, it defaults to hard-coded settings. The CCM Control Task initializes the other CSCs by either calling their initialization functions or, if they have associated tasks, by using the VxWorks® function, taskSpawn(), to create the task. During the initialization of a CSC, it provides the startup defaults from EEPROM as parameters to the task's initialization function. Additionally, ccmInit() sets up the command length verification table by calling ccmCmdLengthInit(). This table is used by the command processor to verify the expected lengths of newly received commands.
293e3939-9502-31cd-9854-9e670c080dfd:
The Command and Control (CCM) CSC is a Level 2 reusable component from the INSTRUMENT Y project. It comprises the following elements: 
* A Control Task, ccmCtrlTask(), responsible for initializing the DPU FSW, spawning other tasks during bootup, scheduling the creation of DPU housekeeping data packets, overseeing the execution of other tasks, and scheduling periodic tasks like the heartbeat message and watchdog strobe.
* A Command Dispatch Task, ccmCmdTask(), which handles receiving and dispatching real-time commands from the SCU or ICU.
Key data structures include:
* A Static Data table that tracks the operational state, containing information such as housekeeping production rates, CCM-specific flags, and the count of executed commands.
* A Command Queue where commands are placed upon arrival via interrupt from the ICU or SCU.
* An Error/Event Queue that collects error and event codes reported by the DPU FSW. These codes are periodically removed from the queue, placed into a telemetry packet, and included in DPU housekeeping data.
1d6d2027-be74-30ee-9f65-2b0e262080e7: The CCM Control Task is responsible for managing memory dump commands. When a data dump command is received, it will divide the dump into smaller, manageable segments and process a portion each time the task is activated. This "deferred" approach is intended to prevent a large dump from monopolizing CPU time and occupying the high-priority CCM Command Dispatch Task for too long.
3d8152f1-fd7f-360d-a294-23085e39b4d2: This function allows setting the data timeout for the DCI, with the specified value representing the timeout in milliseconds. The initial frame depth setting is based on the parameter given when initiating the tmaliTask. The timeout can be set up to a maximum of X seconds; if a larger value is attempted, the timeout will default to X milliseconds.
cb4e8333-2969-3ad9-a029-7cca20cb4af0: The public function retrieves housekeeping data for the TMALI CSC, including some DCI parameters, and resets the internal counters to zero. If the provided pointer to a TMALI_HK structure is NIL, no data is returned, but the counters are still reset. Two of the four error counters are updated in an ISR context, necessitating a task switch-safe implementation. In VxWorks, this could be achieved with a counting semaphore, but the TMALI CSC design uses a faster method with a free-running error counter and a temporary variable for careful error count updates. Since incrementing and assigning 32-bit unsigned integers are atomic operations, the counters are task-safe, ensuring no error events are missed. Consequently, the total errors reported by the tmaliHkGet() function match the actual number of errors that occurred, with no loss of error reports during internal structure updates.
ca4a8f58-ec68-3517-93b1-d3a00b1c33cf: Public Functions: This routine waits on a semaphore when there is no data in the TMALI queue, until events become available as signaled by the ISR. If data is already present in the TMALI queue or the semaphore is acquired, it calculates and returns the number of events in the TMALI queue to the caller. The 'TickstoWait' parameter defines the maximum wait time for data availability in kernel-ticks. This parameter can be set to 'FOREVER', making the function return only when data is available. If a timeout is specified and no data appears within that time, the function returns zero (indicating no events available). If the tmali task is uninitialized, the function returns an error.
0efef385-b1b5-3b97-a569-13031537698b: If an upload exceeds 65535 bytes, it must be divided into smaller files, each no larger than 65535 bytes, and these smaller uploads should be sent sequentially. The DPU FSW can handle receiving these uploads out of order due to sequence numbers. There is no deadline for completing a single upload, allowing it to span multiple ground contacts. During an ongoing upload, the last sequence number can be sent to the DPU FSW, which will then provide a list of any missing sequence numbers through event number S_ccm_MISSING_SEQNO. If an upload needs to be stopped, it can be canceled by using the D_MEM_DAT_CNCL command.
e289c95b-ac5c-3a3f-825d-26dfcfdb180b: Determining the ideal frame depth in DCI will be based on benchmark tests. The default frame depth is set to 10 frames. Based on the provided information, reading 10 frames of maximum size at the highest data transfer rate will take about 24 milliseconds.
113d74ce-4804-3c8a-afe0-7baab53f76db: This function allows configuring the bit arrangement for the DCI. If bSpecialArrangement is set to TRUE, the DCI will use a special bit arrangement mode; otherwise, it will use the default mode with no rearrangement.
4fa926ed-02cb-3af6-ac5f-b24d565928c1: The TMALI CSC comprises the following elements: a ring buffer-based queue, TMALI_EVENT_QUEUE, which stores detector events received from the DCI Driver via the data capture interface until they are accessed by the DPA CSC; an API that allows the DPA CSC to retrieve detector events from the queue, featuring the functions tmaliNextEvent() and tmaliWait(); a set of API functions for the DPA CSC to configure the DCI interface, including tmaliBitArrangementSet(), tmaliDciFrameDepthGet(), tmaliDciFrameDepthSet(), tmaliDciWindowSet(), tmaliDataTimeoutSet(), and tmaliDataTimeoutGet(); an API housekeeping function, tmaliHkGet(), which collects CSC housekeeping data upon request from the Command and Control Task; the task tmaliTask() and an ISR tmaliTransferToQueueISR() that use a semaphore to coordinate data transfer from the DCI to the queue; and an error handling ISR, tmaliDciErrorReportedISR(), which is attached as a hook routine to the DCI Driver to monitor the number of errors reported by the DCI driver.
c7f21260-eae8-339e-b978-139724d9aa8f: This function retrieves the frame depth of the Ping-Pong buffers utilized by the DCI CSC. The frame depth specifies the number of frames loaded into the chosen Ping-Pong buffer before triggering an interrupt. The initial frame depth value is set by the parameter given when starting the tmaliTask. The function returns the currently active value, which might differ from the last set value, as the set value only becomes effective when data is moved from the hardware Ping-Pong buffer to the TMALI queue, triggered by a frame or timeout interrupt (refer to section 5.13.2.3).
531c26c7-bb61-3fd0-9bf9-97720aae74e9: The ccmErrEnq() function monitors the most recent error and how often it occurs. Once an error code is logged, it becomes the last recorded error code managed by ccmErrEnq(). A repetition counter is increased for each subsequent, consecutive occurrence of this same error. If the error code is logged multiple times within a single high-rate housekeeping reporting period, a special error, S_ccm_ERR_REPEAT, is queued with the repetition count included in the least significant byte. This process helps prevent housekeeping telemetry from being overwhelmed by a single recurring error.
d8d54117-035c-3efc-9cee-0f47b77ee01a: The function ccmErrEnq() can be invoked from an interrupt context, where using the mutual exclusion mechanism on the Error Queue is not possible because semaphores cannot be used in this context. To work around this, the global variable ccmISRerror is assigned the relevant error code. The error will be added to the queue the next time ccmTask() is executed. However, because of how errors are managed in interrupt context, if multiple errors occur before ccmTask() runs, earlier errors may be lost as they will be overwritten by subsequent errors.
c6d34b39-6420-3e4f-8df8-0ac776b6bfb8: Each DPU FSW task calls this routine to indicate its execution, allowing ccmCtrlTask() to evaluate the health of the DPU FSW operation.
4864abe7-fe3a-3c5f-a9ed-c0d5ba64c1b6: When a command is received from the SCU through the 1553 interface or from the ICU via the SSI interface, the corresponding ISR will add the command packet to a Command Queue and signal the semaphore to activate the ccmCmdTask(). Since the DPU can send commands to itself, commands might be received in either interrupt or task context. As a result, the CCM uses two separate queues: one for interrupt context that does not use semaphore protection, and another for task context that is semaphore protected.
79dcc3e9-d54d-3750-b120-780bb50dece9: The ring buffer data structure is designed such that its management is straightforward, but one slot is unused when the buffer is full, with the pIn pointer being just before the pOut pointer. The buffer is considered empty when the pIn and pOut pointers are at the same position.
a8cf3e73-2374-3636-97bc-ba6b96c26814: Once the events in the Ping-Pong buffer are fully transferred to the TMALI_EVENT_QUEUE, the tamliTask() function must reset the hardware to switch the Ping-Pong buffer when ready. If TMALI doesn't complete transferring data from the ping buffer before the pong buffer fills up, the DCI Driver will trigger an error interrupt, calling the tmaliDciErrorReportedISR(). This ISR will set an error flag for the tmaliTask() to handle the situation. It also signals the semDciWait semaphore to wake up the tmaliTask(), even though it might already be active, as the task might have just finished transferring data when the error happens. The error will be logged in TMALI_HK. The DCI hardware will ignore events until the tmaliTask() finishes the previous transfer, detects the error flag, and manually forces a Ping-Pong swap to resume data acquisition. This ensures only complete frames are in the Ping-Pong buffer for processing. Normally, this error shouldn't occur because the TMALI task should be quick enough to clear data from the DCI Ping-Pong buffer. If events can't be processed quickly enough, it should lead to a TMALI queue full condition, reported as an S_TMALI_QUEUE_FULL error using the ccmErrEnq() method.
c17c0645-8989-3837-990b-51075afbeaac: The S_ccm_ERR_REPEAT error includes the count of the last repeated error in its lowest byte. When a new error is reported, as previously described, ccmErrEnq() will add a S_ccm_ERR_REPEAT for any error that was repeated before, along with the new error. To ensure that the original error codes and their repeat counts remain in the same error packet, ccmMkHkErr() adds a special error code, S_ccm_ERRQ_FLUSH, to signal ccmErrEnq() to reset its error tracking system and add any repeat error counts linked to a specific error.
bf5d0644-d699-373a-9e5a-4e9f9f009e8e: During startup, the TMALI CSC sets up an ISR hook function, tmaliTransferToQueueISR(), within the DCI Driver. This function is triggered when either the DCI interface hits the set frame limit in the Ping-Pong buffer or when a data receipt timeout is detected by the DCI interface.
69fb7dd4-7a27-3ccf-9f9e-875931f7e50b: In a ring buffer data structure, a distinct pointer, pEnd, marks the buffer's final available position. Before moving any pointer, check if it is at the last position; if so, reset it to the buffer's start, indicated by pBuf. Otherwise, simply increment the pointer.
c71bf77e-ff90-3912-b460-4864f0c87792: The TMALI CSC is set up by launching the tmaliTask() using the default startup parameters. This task will allocate memory for the TMALI_EVENT_QUEUE, set up DCI ISRs, initialize static variables and data structures, and then enter a continuous loop where it moves data from the DCI to the TMALI queue, regulated by the semaphore semDciWait.
16bfac63-131f-3b8a-9fb7-f936ee839740: The TMALI CSC acts as an intermediary for managing EVENT data provided by the DCI Driver CSC, which is ultimately sent to the DPA CSC. TMALI waits for a signal from the DCI CSC indicating that a frame limit or data timeout has been reached in the Ping-Pong buffer, signifying that the EVENT data is ready for TMALI. TMALI then reads all EVENT data from the DCI and informs the DCI that it can switch Ping-Pong buffers when ready. TMALI releases a semaphore to unblock the tmaliWait() call from the DPA.
